captions.text:
Video games have depicted just about every form of 
conflict that exists. Melee. Ranged. Sporting. The

conflict within the mind of a Japanese high school 
student as he decides which member of his social

circle he most wants to fuck. But there&#39;s one 
extremely rich seam of conflict that has, until

now, remained completely untapped: the arena of 
turn-of-the-millennium-era reality television. Who

of a certain generation does not recall the first 
time they saw an orange-tinted woman in a leopard

print skirt screaming in a voice like a guinea 
pig disappearing under a lawnmower at a glistening

shirtless dude with the body of a chiseled Adonis 
and the head of a fourteen-year-old with frosted

tips because his homeschooling never taught him 
not to put baked beans into the dishwasher soap

compartment and thought to themselves, &quot;Boy, I&#39;ve 
never been more conflicted over whether I want to

fuck someone or have them rounded up into camps.&quot; 
And speaking of things I have very complicated

feelings about, let&#39;s talk about Crush House. A 
new indie game from Devolver Digital that places

innovative gameplay design against a setting 
of retro reality television and may make you,

too, wonder which aspect most makes you 
want to put your fist through the screen.

Crush House refers to itself as a &quot;thirst-person 
shooter&quot; then pauses like it&#39;s expecting a fucking

round of applause. It&#39;s a first-person game in 
which you are the producer of a reality TV show

in which four infuriating, young, attractive 
people of varying demeanors and interests hang

around a Malibu beach house forging friendships 
and enemyships on a minute-by-minute basis,

often with the same people, while throughout the 
course of each in-game day, you point the camera

at things the audience might find interesting and 
not point the camera at things to earn advertising

revenue, hoping on one front to point at enough 
interesting things to avoid getting pulled off

the air and on the other to make enough money to 
buy more interesting things to point at. But as

you meet your targets day after day, hints of a 
sinister undercurrent begin to emerge. Where did

these people come from? Why does every season end 
with you and the cast having to jump down a chute,

and why does the next season always 
begin with the production assistant

talking to us like we&#39;ve never met before? 
And how could an interior designer put this

house together without wanting to hang 
themselves on the magenta chandeliers?

Now comes the token paragraph where I praise 
things. I&#39;m always drawn to innovative game

design, and the way Crush House gamifies the 
process of exploiting millennial shitheads is

quite interesting. Each day, you randomly roll 
a selection of audiences who&#39;ll be tuning in,

like foot fetishists and people who are 
inordinately intrigued by sofa cushions,

and have to strategically point the camera 
at the things that those audiences like as

little colorful icons ping off them. Mostly 
intuitive, but I&#39;m not sure why the symbol

for the audience that likes watching girls is a 
carabiner; maybe that&#39;s some hilarious sex joke

for young people that&#39;s going over my head akin to 
the symbol being a clam or a ham sandwich. While

the procedurally generated drama that unfolds 
between the housemates becomes increasingly

repetitive and uninteresting—I fondly recall at 
one point watching two of them become lovers,

snog, move to a different room, and then violently 
break up—that&#39;s arguably intended as you progress

in the plot and become more aware of how the 
show itself is just a tissue-thin veneer over

the real story. It&#39;s sort of a time loop 
game, actually, not unlike Twelve Minutes,

although the cringeworthy affection doesn&#39;t 
lead to quite so many incest babies.

And speaking of malformed issues, praise 
time over, let&#39;s talk about Crush House&#39;s

problems. Starting with the superficial: the way 
it looks. I wouldn&#39;t call it &quot;repellent,&quot; exactly,

and &quot;grotesque&quot; is a pretty strong word. &quot;Yeah, 
&#39;apophasia&#39;s a pretty strong word as well,

isn&#39;t it, Yahtz!&quot; SHUT UP, YOU. All the characters 
have little tiny heads and giant elephantine feet

so they look like forced-perspective drawings 
being looked at wrong. And it doesn&#39;t help that

the environment looks like someone replaced 
your contact lenses with candy love hearts.

But Crush House&#39;s main problem is mechanical. It 
has set itself the ever-daunting task of making

a game out of a creative or artistic 
process, and as is so often the case,

that becomes less about artistry and more 
about learning to manipulate the system.

Much as I found in Bomb Rush Cyberfunk that I 
could ollie off the fucking bridge of Vladimir

Putin&#39;s nose and it still wouldn&#39;t earn 
as many spectacle points as circling a

fucking grind rail for 15 minutes like the last 
undercooked blobfish on the midnight sushi train,

I swiftly found that actually trying to film 
an interesting TV show about the housemates

was a very efficient way to get booted off the 
air faster than an Al Jolson makeup tutorial.

Filming the character drama only earns you points 
if there&#39;s a drama-liking audience present, and

even then, the housemates might randomly decide to 
play Scattergories all day and leave you scouring

the bushes two minutes before deadline looking for 
an aggressive, photogenic spider. To counteract

that possibility, if you max out one of your 
audience requests but continue filming the same

stuff, it&#39;ll count for all your other audiences, 
which successfully prevents your task becoming

impossible but doesn&#39;t make a lot of sense in 
context and incentivizes you to film the same

stuff over and over again. One time, my random 
audience consisted of art lovers, the motion sick,

and people who like calming television. And so by 
pointing the camera at a blank artist&#39;s canvas and

remaining perfectly still for about a minute, I 
proceeded to set fucking box office records. And

meanwhile, the housemates could&#39;ve been having a 
fucking knife fight across the house, and neither

I nor the viewing public gave a shit. And as the 
difficulty ramps up and your audiences get more

demanding, this kind of number manipulation 
becomes essential for beating the game.

So, after putting in the hours filming 
static toilets and drinks machines from

artful Dutch angles, I&#39;d have all the 
requirements fulfilled by mid-afternoon,

and with nothing else to be gained from filming 
anything, I&#39;d just earn money playing ads back to

back while idly seeing if I could clip into 
the poolside umbrellas. But my feelings for

Crush House are mixed because as boring 
and repetitive as the core gameplay and

housemate interactions got, it was all on theme. 
Of course, the housemates are cardboard cutouts,

and the audience will happily watch static shots 
of fucking pot plants. That&#39;s reality television:

as tissue-thin and suffocatingly banal as a 
chloroform rag. The real plot only advances

when you fulfil the secret objectives 
the housemates give you on the down-low,

usually to film them snogging or film their 
buttocks for three minutes straight, which does

give you something to strive for. Although again, 
fulfilling them comes down to random chance,

and when you get down to it, being boring for 
stylistic reasons doesn&#39;t make you LESS boring.

Still, what ultimately clinches a recommendation 
for Crush House is that it is both interesting

enough and not very long. You&#39;ll have plenty of 
time left in the week to complete the reality

television experience by watching a farmyard 
cockfight while slamming your hand in a drawer.
